headline: Government Passes Urgent Law to Suspend Many Overseas Adoptions Amid Child Safety Fears
summary: Parliament passed urgent legislation to temporarily halt overseas adoptions from many countries, citing risks of child trafficking and exploitation. The move, which passed in a single day with cross-party support, dominated a session that also saw fierce clashes between the Prime Minister and Opposition Leader over the rising cost of living, and major government announcements on competition law and Auckland transport reform.

topicSummaries.topic: Urgent Bill Halting Many Overseas Adoptions Passed in Single Day
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The new law immediately stops New Zealanders from adopting children from many countries, including several Pacific nations, to prevent child trafficking and exploitation.
topicSummaries.content: The government passed the Adoption Amendment Bill through all stages under urgency, temporarily suspending New Zealand's recognition of overseas adoptions from countries not on an approved list. Associate Justice Minister Nicole McKee introduced the bill, stating it was necessary to close a legislative loophole that has allowed children to be adopted into situations of "neglect, abuse, or exploitation." The bill creates an exempt list of 86 countries deemed to have sufficient safeguards, largely based on the Hague convention. While all parties supported the bill's intent to protect children, Labour and the Greens raised concerns that it was a "blunt tool" passed without proper consultation, which would prevent legitimate adoptions and negatively impact families, particularly in the Pacific.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Nicole McKee (Associate Minister of Justice)
keyExchanges.quote: It is not acceptable that our adoption laws have been used in ways that harm children adopted from overseas. We must close this legislative enabler.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr Duncan Webb (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill does appear to be a relatively blunt tool. We know that adoption is misused... But this bill will preclude legitimate adoptions from countries that aren't exempt, and it must be said that amongst those are some of our Pacific neighbours.

topicSummaries.topic: PM and Opposition Leader Clash Over Soaring Food and Household Costs
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The debate highlights the core political battle over who is responsible for rising prices on essentials like food, power, and insurance, which directly affect family budgets.
topicSummaries.content: A heated exchange during Question Time saw Opposition Leader Chris Hipkins challenge Prime Minister Christopher Luxon on the government's handling of the cost of living. Hipkins cited recent statistics showing a 32% increase in the price of butter and mince reaching $22 a kilo, alongside a 10.8% rise in government-influenced 'administered inflation'. Luxon defended his government's record, stating overall inflation was back under 3% and food inflation at 5% was significantly lower than the 12.5% peak under the previous government. He attributed elevated meat and dairy prices to global commodities and pointed to tax relief and supermarket competition reforms as measures to help families.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: If his Government has inflation under control, as he is now claiming, why is the price of food continuing to increase, with statistics released today showing butter is up 32 percent, milk is up by almost $1, and the price of mince is now $22 a kilo, all under his leadership?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (Prime Minister)
keyExchanges.quote: Well, I'd just remind the member that when he was Prime Minister, food inflation hit 12.5 percent. It is 5 percent today. Yes, we have elevated prices for red meat and for dairy products. That's due to global commodity prices, and that's why our farmers are having record years and record levels of farmer confidence in this country.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Unveils Major Overhaul of Competition Laws
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: These reforms aim to increase competition in sectors like groceries and fuel, which could eventually lead to more choice and better prices for consumers.
topicSummaries.content: Minister for Economic Growth Nicola Willis announced a significant package of reforms to the Commerce Act, describing it as the largest in nearly 20 years. The changes are designed to foster competition by stopping tactics like 'creeping acquisitions' where dominant firms quietly buy up rivals, and cracking down on predatory pricing. The government argues this will give small and medium businesses more confidence to invest and innovate. However, Labour's Arena Williams questioned whether the reforms would do anything to bring down the price of essentials for consumers now, with Willis conceding that while it was not a "quick fix," it was a substantive reform to prevent future market consolidation.

keyExchanges.speaker: Arena Williams (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Well, will any of the inclusions in the announcement today reduce food prices, which are up 5 percent this year and driving up inflation?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Nicola Willis (National)
keyExchanges.quote: I hope that the member understands the fundamental nature of competition law... not everything in life is a quick fix but that doesn't mean that we should ignore the opportunities for substantive reform.

topicSummaries.topic: Bill to Overhaul Auckland Transport Governance Introduced
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The proposed changes would give Auckland's elected councillors and local boards direct control over most transport decisions, from road maintenance to cycleways, increasing democratic accountability.
topicSummaries.content: The government introduced a bill to reform transport governance in Auckland, transferring most functions from the council-controlled organisation Auckland Transport back to the elected Auckland Council. Minister for Auckland Simeon Brown stated the move would restore democratic accountability, aligning Auckland with every other council in the country. The bill will empower local boards to make decisions on local roads, including setting speed limits and managing parking. Labour supported the bill to select committee, with Deputy Leader Carmel Sepuloni framing it as the correction of a mistake made by the National-led government that created the 'anti-democratic' CCO structure in 2009, and credited Auckland Mayor Wayne Brown for championing the change.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Simeon Brown (National)
keyExchanges.quote: Public trust and confidence in transport decision making in Auckland is low... So ensuring democratic accountability for decision making for transport in Auckland is a key element of these reforms.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Carmel Sepuloni (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: We were opposed to the anti-democratic establishment of the Auckland Transport council-controlled organisation that was set up under their watch. It's only taken them 16 years to come to this House and say that they were wrong.

topicSummaries.topic: Minister Questioned on Deadly Delays for Blood Cancer Patients
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: Patients with curable blood cancers are reportedly becoming incurable while waiting for stem cell transplants, raising urgent questions about healthcare capacity and funding.
topicSummaries.content: Labour's Health spokesperson Dr Ayesha Verrall pressed the Minister of Health, Simeon Brown, on the impact of delays for allogeneic stem cell transplants. Dr Verrall questioned if the failure to implement the government's own health targets plan meant patients' cancers were becoming incurable while on wait-lists. Minister Brown acknowledged the situation was "deeply concerning," stating that for some patients, disease recurs while waiting, meaning they are no longer suitable for a transplant and may be referred to palliative care. He said Health New Zealand had allocated over $6 million to increase capacity and that transplant numbers had risen slightly, but conceded it was "not good enough" and he expected urgent action.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr Ayesha Verrall (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Is it correct that failure to implement their very own plan in the first year that it was put down for means patients like Liz Barnes, whose cancer was curable, now have incurable cancer?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Simeon Brown (Minister of Health)
keyExchanges.quote: Well, as I said in my previous answer, there has been an increase in the number of transplants being completed. There is still significantly more work to be done. That work is under way so that we can reduce that wait-list, and it's my expectation that Health New Zealand works incredibly close with the clinicians on the front line to do just that.

conclusion: The government used its majority to urgently pass child protection legislation while facing intense pressure from the opposition over the cost of living and the state of the health system.
